title: Third and Six
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.2     ✔ readr     2.1.4
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
✔ ggplot2   3.4.3     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.2     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(cfbfastR)

title: Third and Six
section: Of all of the plays run on 3rd and 6, 360 of them were rushing plays. In addition, 20 plays run on 3rd and 6 ended up in rushing touchdowns.
text:
Of all of the plays run on 3rd and 6, 360 of them were rushing plays. In addition, 20 plays run on 3rd and 6 ended up in rushing touchdowns.


Code
play_type_count %>% 
  mutate(total = sum(count)) %>% 
  mutate(percent = (count/total) *100) %>% 
  arrange(desc(percent))


# A tibble: 19 × 4
   play_type                            count total  percent
   <chr>                                <int> <int>    <dbl>
 1 Pass Reception                        3596 12001 30.0    
 2 Pass Incompletion                     2956 12001 24.6    
 3 Rush                                  2420 12001 20.2    
 4 Penalty                                828 12001  6.90   
 5 Timeout                                694 12001  5.78   
 6 Sack                                   631 12001  5.26   
 7 Passing Touchdown                      392 12001  3.27   
 8 Interception Return                    188 12001  1.57   
 9 Rushing Touchdown                      102 12001  0.850  
10 Fumble Recovery (Opponent)              85 12001  0.708  
11 Fumble Recovery (Own)                   56 12001  0.467  
12 Interception Return Touchdown           26 12001  0.217  
13 Field Goal Good                         13 12001  0.108  
14 Field Goal Missed                        4 12001  0.0333 
15 Fumble Return Touchdown                  3 12001  0.0250 
16 Punt                                     3 12001  0.0250 
17 Safety                                   2 12001  0.0167 
18 Blocked Field Goal                       1 12001  0.00833
19 Fumble Recovery (Opponent) Touchdown     1 12001  0.00833

title: Third and Six
section: 18% of plays run on third and six were runs and an additional 1% of rush plays run on third and six resulted in touchdowns.
text:
18% of plays run on third and six were runs and an additional 1% of rush plays run on third and six resulted in touchdowns.


Code
rushing_plays <- third_and_six %>% 
  filter(down == 3, distance == 6, play_type == "Rush") %>% 
  mutate(mean(yards_gained))

title: Third and Six
section: We see that the mean yard average of runs on third down and six on plays that did not end in touchdowns is 5.86.
text:
We see that the mean yard average of runs on third down and six on plays that did not end in touchdowns is 5.86.


Code
rushing2019<-rushing_plays %>%  
  filter(year == '2019')

rushing2020<-rushing_plays %>%  
  filter(year == '2020')

rushing2021<-rushing_plays %>%  
  filter(year == '2021')

rushing2022<-rushing_plays %>%  
  filter(year == '2022')

rushing2023<-rushing_plays %>%  
  filter(year == '2023')

title: Third and Six
section: Out of the four most recent completed seasons and this season so far, teams ran the ball on 3rd and 6 the most in 2022, 748 times. This is more than 200 than the next closest season which is 2021.
text:
Out of the four most recent completed seasons and this season so far, teams ran the ball on 3rd and 6 the most in 2022, 748 times. This is more than 200 than the next closest season which is 2021.


Code
rushing2019 %>% 
  group_by(pos_team) %>% 
  summarise(count =n()) %>% 
  arrange(desc(count))


# A tibble: 151 × 2
   pos_team         count
   <chr>            <int>
 1 Georgia Southern    13
 2 Navy                12
 3 Northwestern        11
 4 Nebraska            10
 5 Buffalo              8
 6 Louisiana            8
 7 Army                 7
 8 Notre Dame           7
 9 Oklahoma State       7
10 Old Dominion         7
# ℹ 141 more rows


Code
rushing2020 %>% 
  group_by(pos_team) %>% 
  summarise(count =n()) %>% 
  arrange(desc(count))


# A tibble: 115 × 2
   pos_team             count
   <chr>                <int>
 1 Navy                    12
 2 Georgia Southern         7
 3 Army                     6
 4 Kansas                   6
 5 Air Force                5
 6 Liberty                  5
 7 Memphis                  5
 8 Southern Mississippi     5
 9 Western Kentucky         5
10 Arkansas                 4
# ℹ 105 more rows


Code
rushing2021 %>% 
  group_by(pos_team) %>% 
  summarise(count =n()) %>% 
  arrange(desc(count))


# A tibble: 147 × 2
   pos_team   count
   <chr>      <int>
 1 Army          16
 2 Baylor        13
 3 Arkansas      10
 4 Louisiana     10
 5 Air Force      9
 6 Kent State     9
 7 Navy           9
 8 New Mexico     9
 9 Rice           9
10 Utah State     8
# ℹ 137 more rows


Code
rushing2022 %>% 
  group_by(pos_team) %>% 
  summarise(count =n()) %>% 
  arrange(desc(count))


# A tibble: 237 × 2
   pos_team           count
   <chr>              <int>
 1 Navy                  13
 2 Kennesaw State        12
 3 The Citadel           10
 4 Army                   9
 5 William & Mary         9
 6 Auburn                 8
 7 Duke                   8
 8 Florida State          8
 9 South Dakota State     8
10 UNLV                   8
# ℹ 227 more rows


Code
rushing2023 %>% 
  group_by(pos_team) %>% 
  summarise(count =n()) %>% 
  arrange(desc(count))


# A tibble: 193 × 2
   pos_team       count
   <chr>          <int>
 1 South Florida      8
 2 West Virginia      7
 3 Air Force          6
 4 Boston College     6
 5 UAB                6
 6 Army               5
 7 Cal Poly           5
 8 Prairie View       5
 9 Utah               5
10 Bowling Green      4
# ℹ 183 more rows

title: Third and Six
section: So far this season, South Florida has run the ball on 3rd and 6 the most doing it 6 times. In the other four recent years, Navy led the nation twice, Army did it once, and Georgia Southern did it once. Navy and Army both run the triple option so it makes a lot of sense that they would be at or near the top of these lists.
text:
So far this season, South Florida has run the ball on 3rd and 6 the most doing it 6 times. In the other four recent years, Navy led the nation twice, Army did it once, and Georgia Southern did it once. Navy and Army both run the triple option so it makes a lot of sense that they would be at or near the top of these lists.


Code
Maryland <- third_and_six %>% 
  filter(pos_team == "Maryland")




Code
Maryland %>% 
  group_by(play_type) %>% 
  summarise(count=n()) %>% 
  arrange(desc(count))


# A tibble: 10 × 2
   play_type                  count
   <chr>                      <int>
 1 Rush                          15
 2 Pass Reception                13
 3 Pass Incompletion             11
 4 Passing Touchdown              4
 5 Sack                           4
 6 Fumble Recovery (Opponent)     2
 7 Penalty                        2
 8 Timeout                        2
 9 Interception Return            1
10 Rushing Touchdown              1

title: Third and Six
section: It seems that the third and six run by Maryland on Saturday against Illinois was not an anamoly. Maryland has rushed the ball 15 times on third and six in the last five seasons. They have thrown the ball 24 times, completing 13 of those passes. Maryland has also rushed for one touchdown on 3rd and 6 in the last five years as well.
text: It seems that the third and six run by Maryland on Saturday against Illinois was not an anamoly. Maryland has rushed the ball 15 times on third and six in the last five seasons. They have thrown the ball 24 times, completing 13 of those passes. Maryland has also rushed for one touchdown on 3rd and 6 in the last five years as well.

text:
Code
library(tidyverse)

Code
logs22<-read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs22.csv")


Rows: 1672 Columns: 54
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (8): HomeAway, Opponent, Result, TeamFull, TeamURL, Outcome, Team, Con...

date  (1): Date

ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

Rows: 970 Columns: 54
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (8): HomeAway, Opponent, Result, TeamFull, TeamURL, Outcome, Team, Con...
dbl  (45): Game, PassingCmp, PassingAtt, PassingPct, PassingYds, PassingTD, ...

title: Big Ten PLays
section: Here, I am filtering out only the Big Ten teams from the data as well as adding up the number of offensive plays ran by Big Ten teams in 2022.
text:
Here, I am filtering out only the Big Ten teams from the data as well as adding up the number of offensive plays ran by Big Ten teams in 2022.


Code
BigTen22<-logs22 %>% 
  group_by(Conference, Team) %>% 
  summarise(TotalPlays = sum(OffensivePlays)) %>% 
  filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference")


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'Conference'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

title: Big Ten PLays
section: I am dividing the total number of plays by 13 because that is the number of games that most teams play per season.
text:
I am dividing the total number of plays by 13 because that is the number of games that most teams play per season.


Code
Averages<-BigTen22 %>% 
  mutate(mean = TotalPlays/13)

title: Big Ten PLays
section: Here is the bar chart for 2022 plays.
text:
Here is the bar chart for 2022 plays.


Code
ggplot()+
  geom_bar(
    data=Averages,
    aes(x=Team, weight=mean)
  )







Code
BigTen23<-logs23 %>% 
  group_by(Conference, Team) %>% 
  summarise(TotalPlays = sum(OffensivePlays)) %>% 
  filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference")


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'Conference'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

title: Big Ten PLays
section: I am dividing this time by 6 because that is the number of games a majority of teams have played.
text:
I am dividing this time by 6 because that is the number of games a majority of teams have played.


Code
Averages23<-BigTen23 %>% 
  mutate(mean = TotalPlays/6)




Code
ggplot()+
  geom_bar(
    data=Averages23,
    aes(x=Team, weight=mean))

title: Big Ten PLays
section: Immediately, one of the things that stands out to me is that Maryland’s bar is higher than a majority of the other bars meaning they typically run more plays per game than a lot of Big Ten teams. Maryland has had a pretty good offense the last couple of seasons so this makes sense. AS a whole, it does appear that the number of offensive plays run per game is decreasing. On the 2022 chart, the plays column goes up to 80, while it only goes up to 60 in 2023. Purdue led the conference in total plays ran last season and are leading again this season, but the number of plays they run per game has dropped thanks to the new rules.
text: Immediately, one of the things that stands out to me is that Maryland’s bar is higher than a majority of the other bars meaning they typically run more plays per game than a lot of Big Ten teams. Maryland has had a pretty good offense the last couple of seasons so this makes sense. AS a whole, it does appear that the number of offensive plays run per game is decreasing. On the 2022 chart, the plays column goes up to 80, while it only goes up to 60 in 2023. Purdue led the conference in total plays ran last season and are leading again this season, but the number of plays they run per game has dropped thanks to the new rules.

title: Hello World
text:
Welcome to this, surely the greatest blog I have ever published, and I have published blogs since 1997.
I hope the Atlanta Braves win the World Series.

library(cfbfastR)

title: Third and Six
section: Of all of the plays run on 3rd and 6, 360 of them were rushing plays. In addition, 20 plays run on 3rd and 6 ended up in rushing touchdowns.
text:
Of all of the plays run on 3rd and 6, 360 of them were rushing plays. In addition, 20 plays run on 3rd and 6 ended up in rushing touchdowns.


Code
play_type_count %>% 
  mutate(total = sum(count)) %>% 
  mutate(percent = (count/total) *100) %>% 
  arrange(desc(percent))


# A tibble: 19 × 4
   play_type                            count total  percent
   <chr>                                <int> <int>    <dbl>
 1 Pass Reception                        3596 12001 30.0    
 2 Pass Incompletion                     2956 12001 24.6    
 3 Rush                                  2420 12001 20.2    
 4 Penalty                                828 12001  6.90   
 5 Timeout                                694 12001  5.78   
 6 Sack                                   631 12001  5.26   
 7 Passing Touchdown                      392 12001  3.27   
 8 Interception Return                    188 12001  1.57   
 9 Rushing Touchdown                      102 12001  0.850  
10 Fumble Recovery (Opponent)              85 12001  0.708  
11 Fumble Recovery (Own)                   56 12001  0.467  
12 Interception Return Touchdown           26 12001  0.217  
13 Field Goal Good                         13 12001  0.108  
14 Field Goal Missed                        4 12001  0.0333 
15 Fumble Return Touchdown                  3 12001  0.0250 
16 Punt                                     3 12001  0.0250 
17 Safety                                   2 12001  0.0167 
18 Blocked Field Goal                       1 12001  0.00833
19 Fumble Recovery (Opponent) Touchdown     1 12001  0.00833

title: Third and Six
section: 18% of plays run on third and six were runs and an additional 1% of rush plays run on third and six resulted in touchdowns.
text:
18% of plays run on third and six were runs and an additional 1% of rush plays run on third and six resulted in touchdowns.


Code
rushing_plays <- third_and_six %>% 
  filter(down == 3, distance == 6, play_type == "Rush") %>% 
  mutate(mean(yards_gained))

title: Third and Six
section: We see that the mean yard average of runs on third down and six on plays that did not end in touchdowns is 5.86.
text:
We see that the mean yard average of runs on third down and six on plays that did not end in touchdowns is 5.86.


Code
rushing2019<-rushing_plays %>%  
  filter(year == '2019')

rushing2020<-rushing_plays %>%  
  filter(year == '2020')

rushing2021<-rushing_plays %>%  
  filter(year == '2021')

rushing2022<-rushing_plays %>%  
  filter(year == '2022')

rushing2023<-rushing_plays %>%  
  filter(year == '2023')

title: Third and Six
section: Out of the four most recent completed seasons and this season so far, teams ran the ball on 3rd and 6 the most in 2022, 748 times. This is more than 200 than the next closest season which is 2021.
text:
Out of the four most recent completed seasons and this season so far, teams ran the ball on 3rd and 6 the most in 2022, 748 times. This is more than 200 than the next closest season which is 2021.


Code
rushing2019 %>% 
  group_by(pos_team) %>% 
  summarise(count =n()) %>% 
  arrange(desc(count))


# A tibble: 151 × 2
   pos_team         count
   <chr>            <int>
 1 Georgia Southern    13
 2 Navy                12
 3 Northwestern        11
 4 Nebraska            10
 5 Buffalo              8
 6 Louisiana            8
 7 Army                 7
 8 Notre Dame           7
 9 Oklahoma State       7
10 Old Dominion         7
# ℹ 141 more rows

  group_by(pos_team) %>% 
  summarise(count =n()) %>% 
  arrange(desc(count))

title: Third and Six
section: So far this season, South Florida has run the ball on 3rd and 6 the most doing it 6 times. In the other four recent years, Navy led the nation twice, Army did it once, and Georgia Southern did it once. Navy and Army both run the triple option so it makes a lot of sense that they would be at or near the top of these lists.
text:
So far this season, South Florida has run the ball on 3rd and 6 the most doing it 6 times. In the other four recent years, Navy led the nation twice, Army did it once, and Georgia Southern did it once. Navy and Army both run the triple option so it makes a lot of sense that they would be at or near the top of these lists.


Code
Maryland <- third_and_six %>% 
  filter(pos_team == "Maryland")




Code
Maryland %>% 
  group_by(play_type) %>% 
  summarise(count=n()) %>% 
  arrange(desc(count))


# A tibble: 10 × 2
   play_type                  count
   <chr>                      <int>
 1 Rush                          15
 2 Pass Reception                13
 3 Pass Incompletion             11
 4 Passing Touchdown              4
 5 Sack                           4
 6 Fumble Recovery (Opponent)     2
 7 Penalty                        2
 8 Timeout                        2
 9 Interception Return            1
10 Rushing Touchdown              1

title: Third and Six
section: It seems that the third and six run by Maryland on Saturday against Illinois was not an anamoly. Maryland has rushed the ball 15 times on third and six in the last five seasons. They have thrown the ball 24 times, completing 13 of those passes. Maryland has also rushed for one touchdown on 3rd and 6 in the last five years as well.
text: It seems that the third and six run by Maryland on Saturday against Illinois was not an anamoly. Maryland has rushed the ball 15 times on third and six in the last five seasons. They have thrown the ball 24 times, completing 13 of those passes. Maryland has also rushed for one touchdown on 3rd and 6 in the last five years as well.

I hope the Atlanta Braves win the World Series.

title: Big Ten PLays
section: Here, I am filtering out only the Big Ten teams from the data as well as adding up the number of offensive plays ran by Big Ten teams in 2022.
text:
Here, I am filtering out only the Big Ten teams from the data as well as adding up the number of offensive plays ran by Big Ten teams in 2022.


Code
BigTen22<-logs22 %>% 
  group_by(Conference, Team) %>% 
  summarise(TotalPlays = sum(OffensivePlays)) %>% 
  filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference")


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'Conference'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

title: Big Ten PLays
section: I am dividing the total number of plays by 13 because that is the number of games that most teams play per season.
text:
I am dividing the total number of plays by 13 because that is the number of games that most teams play per season.


Code
Averages<-BigTen22 %>% 
  mutate(mean = TotalPlays/13)

title: Big Ten PLays
section: Here is the bar chart for 2022 plays.
text:
Here is the bar chart for 2022 plays.


Code
ggplot()+
  geom_bar(
    data=Averages,
    aes(x=Team, weight=mean)
  )







Code
BigTen23<-logs23 %>% 
  group_by(Conference, Team) %>% 
  summarise(TotalPlays = sum(OffensivePlays)) %>% 
  filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference")


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'Conference'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

title: Big Ten PLays
section: I am dividing this time by 6 because that is the number of games a majority of teams have played.
text:
I am dividing this time by 6 because that is the number of games a majority of teams have played.


Code
Averages23<-BigTen23 %>% 
  mutate(mean = TotalPlays/6)




Code
ggplot()+
  geom_bar(
    data=Averages23,
    aes(x=Team, weight=mean))

title: Big Ten PLays
section: Immediately, one of the things that stands out to me is that Maryland’s bar is higher than a majority of the other bars meaning they typically run more plays per game than a lot of Big Ten teams. Maryland has had a pretty good offense the last couple of seasons so this makes sense. AS a whole, it does appear that the number of offensive plays run per game is decreasing. On the 2022 chart, the plays column goes up to 80, while it only goes up to 60 in 2023. Purdue led the conference in total plays ran last season and are leading again this season, but the number of plays they run per game has dropped thanks to the new rules.
text: Immediately, one of the things that stands out to me is that Maryland’s bar is higher than a majority of the other bars meaning they typically run more plays per game than a lot of Big Ten teams. Maryland has had a pretty good offense the last couple of seasons so this makes sense. AS a whole, it does appear that the number of offensive plays run per game is decreasing. On the 2022 chart, the plays column goes up to 80, while it only goes up to 60 in 2023. Purdue led the conference in total plays ran last season and are leading again this season, but the number of plays they run per game has dropped thanks to the new rules.

title: Dolphins EPA
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.2     ✔ readr     2.1.4
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
✔ ggplot2   3.4.3     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.2     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(nflreadr)
library(ggalt)


Registered S3 methods overwritten by 'ggalt':
  method                  from   
  grid.draw.absoluteGrob  ggplot2
  grobHeight.absoluteGrob ggplot2
  grobWidth.absoluteGrob  ggplot2
  grobX.absoluteGrob      ggplot2
  grobY.absoluteGrob      ggplot2
Code
pxp<-load_pbp(2022)
Code
Dolphins <- pxp %>% 
  filter(
    week <4,
    posteam == "MIA",
    yardline_100 <21,
    play_type == "run" | play_type == "pass"
  )
Code
EPAcheck <- sum(Dolphins$epa)
Code
Dolphins_entire_season <- pxp %>% 
  filter(
    posteam == "MIA",
    yardline_100 <21,
    play_type == "run" | play_type == "pass"
  )
Code
EPA_entire_season <- sum(Dolphins_entire_season$epa)

title: Dolphins EPA
section: For the entire 2022 season, the Miami Dolphins EPA improved by 3.7 points.
text:
For the entire 2022 season, the Miami Dolphins EPA improved by 3.7 points.


Code
pxp_week3 <- pxp %>% 
  filter(
    week <4,
    yardline_100 < 21,
    play_type == "run" | play_type == "pass") %>% 
  group_by(posteam)




Code
epa_week3 <- pxp_week3 %>% 
  summarise(
    EPA_Week_3 = sum (epa),
    TotalPlays_Week3 = sum (yardline_100 < 21))




Code
pxp_week8 <- pxp %>% 
  filter(
    week <8,
    yardline_100 < 21,
    play_type == "run" | play_type == "pass") %>% 
  group_by(posteam)




Code
epa_week8 <- pxp_week8 %>% 
  summarise(
    EPA_Week_8 = sum (epa),
    TotalPlays_Week8 = sum (yardline_100 < 21))




Code
EPA_3_and_8<-epa_week3 %>% left_join(epa_week8, join_by("posteam"))




Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_dumbbell(
    data=EPA_3_and_8, 
    aes(y=posteam, x=EPA_Week_3, xend=EPA_Week_8),
        colour_x = "green",
        colour_xend = "blue"
  ) +
labs(title = "2022 NFL EPA's Weeks 3 through 8", x="EPA", y="Team", subtitle = "A lot of different ranges for EPA's for ")


Warning: Using the `size` aesthetic with geom_segment was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use the `linewidth` aesthetic instead.

title: Dolphins EPA
section: There are a lot of different ranges of EPA’s for Weeks 3 through 8 of the 2022 season. There are several outliars on this chart. First, we can see that the Denver Broncos were horrible through the first 3 weeks, and got even worse as the season went on. The Kansas City Chiefs were excellent through week 3 and got even better as the season went on. Several teams have very big ranges between their EPA’s such as Washington and Chicago, and others are very small such as Las Vegas, Tampa Bay and Carolina.
text: There are a lot of different ranges of EPA’s for Weeks 3 through 8 of the 2022 season. There are several outliars on this chart. First, we can see that the Denver Broncos were horrible through the first 3 weeks, and got even worse as the season went on. The Kansas City Chiefs were excellent through week 3 and got even better as the season went on. Several teams have very big ranges between their EPA’s such as Washington and Chicago, and others are very small such as Las Vegas, Tampa Bay and Carolina.
